no_console: &cYou need to be a player to do this
no_permission: &cYou don't have the right permission to do this.
no_task: &cThere is no task with this name
task_execution_ongoing: &aTask is being executed. Not all commands may be executed at once.
and_condition: Every condition need to be true
or_condition: Any condition needs to be true
simple_condition: A condition in it simplest form. Result needs to be true
not_condition: A condition in it simplest form. Result needs to be false
condition_type_lore:
&7The condition type defines the relation
&7between multiple condition parts
condition_parts_lore:
&7Condition parts allow you to create complex
&7conditions to fit your needs. They can
&7also be nested to give you endless
&7possibilities.

&7Try to stick with simple conditions before&7you go crazy on them
simple_condition_lore:
&7A simple condition is a basic comparison between
&72 values. For example &oplayer is OP -> true/false
author: &7Author: &e$1
gender_lore:
&7The commands don't need to be executed all
&7at once. You can decide between one of the
&7following selection modes:

&7  - &eALL: &7Execute all commands at once

&7  - &eORDERED: &7Execute the commands one by one.
&7    This works best if you specify seconds. It will
&7    execute command 1 the first time the task is executed,
&7    then it will pick command 2 on next execution and so on.

&7  - &eRANDOM: &7Same as above, but will pick a random
&7    command at each execution.

&7  - &eINTERVAL: &7Execute each command in order with
&7    an interval in between.
&7    See ORDERED for more information
gender_selector_lore:
&7Genders are one of the core concepts of
&7CommandTimer. They allow you to specify
&7how your task is executed.

&7Current: &e$1

&bAvailable genders:

&7  - &eOPERATOR: &7All the commands in the task
&7    will be executed for each individual player,
&7    by the player. This means that CommandTimer will
&7    force the player to execute the commands but ignore
&7    the permissions linked to them.

&7  - &ePLAYER: &7Same as above. CommandTimer will force
&7    the player to execute the commands, but will take
&7    into account the possible permissions the player
&7    has or is lacking.

&7  - &eCONSOLE: &7Execute the command in the console only

&7  - &eCONSOLE PER USER: &7Execute the command in the console
&7    for each individual player. This works very well with
&7    placeholders

&7  - &eCONSOLE_PER_USER_OFFLINE: &7Same as above but also takes into account offline players

&7  - &eCONSOLE_PROXY: &7Execute commands on proxy (requires proxy extension
add_command_lore:
&7Add a new command that will be
&7executed on your specified schedule
command_interval_lore:
&7Define the delay between each player command execution.
&7This only works when you have a gender that runs
&7for all the players.

&7Current: &e$1
open_commands_settings_lore:
&7Change core command settings that are differentiated
&7from the normal command settings
reset_command_index_lore:
&7CommandTimer keeps track of the last executed command when
&7the execution mode is INTERVAL or ORDERED.
&7Resetting this value will start the command execution
&7from the beginning.

&aLeft-Click to reset
command_delay_lore:
&7Adding a delay command allows you to add a pause after the command
&7before the next command in the task will be executed.
&7This only works when your execution mode is ORDERED

&7Current: &e$1
task_execution_limit_lore:
&7Set a limit on how many times a task
&7can be executed in total
toggle_reset_lore:
&7If enabled, the number of executions
&7will reset after a restart. The actual limit
&7you configured will stay but we will start
&7counting from 0 again.

&7This can be very helpful if you want a task
&7to happen on server start/reload only
execution_limit_lore:
&7Set a limit on how many times
&7a task can be executed in total

&7Current limit: &e$1
&7Current times executed: &e$2
&7Reset on restart: &e$3
time_two_lore:
&7This time can be used if you want a range
&7instead of a specific hour. You could use this
&7to only execute a task between a set of hours, like
&7between 12:00:00 and 14:00:00

&7Current value: &e$1
minecraft_time_lore:
&7If enabled, the configured time will be
&7the time on your Minecraft server
minecraft_time_world_lore:
&7When your time is the minecraft time, you need
&7to specify which world will be used for the time.

&7This does not affect where the actual task is executed

&7Current world: &e$1
add_specific_time_lore:
&7Add a new specific time at which your task
&7should be executed
task_interval_item_lore:
&7Set an interval for this task.

&7This means that your set of commands will be
&7executed every x seconds/minutes on a regular base
task_interval_hours_lore:
&7Configure specific points in time at which
&7your task should be executed.

&7This could for example be 13:15:00, that would
&7execute your task every day at that time
task_interval_days_lore:
&7Set a limit on which days the task
&7can be executed.

&7This works with both seconds and specific points in time.

&7You can for example choose to only execute a task
&7during the weekend, or only on monday,...
create_task_lore:
&7A task consists of:
&7  - A set of conditions
&7  - One or more commands

&7 - Optionally events that will trigger it

&7Based on how you configure it, the commands will be
&7executed when the conditions meet.
change_task_display_name_lore: &7Change the display name of this task
change_task_schedule_settings_lore: &7Choose when this task will be executed
change_task_limits_lore:
&7Add more limits to this task to
&7limit when the task can be executed.

&bAvailable limits:
&7  - Maximum executions
change_task_conditions_lore:
&7Conditions allow you to have an overall
&7control of when your tasks should be executed
&7or when not
task_activation_lore: &7Choose if this task should run or not
events_item_lore:
&7Listen to events instead of relying on 
&7an interval to execute commands.

&7Events are made available by adding
&7extensions to CommandTimer.
configure_event_values_item_lore:
&7Events contain certain values depending on what
&7or who triggered the event. You can compare against these values
all_tasks_lore:
&7Get an overview of your currently
&7loaded tasks. This is also the
&7place where you can create new tasks
integrations_lore:
&7See all possible integrations
&7and the ones that are currently loaded
papi_integration_description:
&7CommandTimer hooks into this integration to
&7use task values like the next execution of
&7a task in another plugin that integrations with
&7PlaceholderAPI
metrics_integration_description:
&7Metrics is an integration to keep track of certain
&7server statistics like player count, what machine
&7you are using,...
description_lore:
&7Set the description for this command

&7Current description: &e$1
scheduled_executions_lore:
&7View all scheduled task executions
&7that will be executed in the future
refresh_button_lore:
&7Click to refresh the list of
&7scheduled executions
filter_button_lore:
&7Click to cycle through filters:
&7  - All
&7  - Tasks Only
&7  - Ad-Hoc Only
